facts.text: Petition filed in Original Jurisdiction as Petition No. 32 of 1959 under Art. 32 of the Constitution of India for enforcement of Fundamental Rights.

anchor.surface_text: ORIGINAL JURISDICTION Petition No. 32 of 1959. Petition under Art. 32 of the Constitution of India for enforcement of Fundamental Rights.

facts.text: Judgment of the Court delivered by K. DAS, J. on March 22, 1961.

anchor.surface_text: 1961. March 22. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by K. DAS, J.-This is a writ petition under Art. 32 of the Constitution.

facts.text: Petitioner's husband Kunhi Moosa Haji carried on a hotel business in Karachi, Pakistan since 1936.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioners husband Kunhi Moosa Haji, it is alleged, carried on a hotel business in Karachi which is number in Pakistan. The petitioner stated that her husband had been carrying on the said business since 1936.

facts.text: In 1947, when the separate dominion of Pakistan was set up, petitioner's husband was in Karachi.

anchor.surface_text: It is number in dispute, however, that in the relevant year, that is, 1947, when the separate dominion of Pakistan was set up, the petitioners husband was in Karachi.

facts.text: Petitioner's husband returned to Malabar, India at the end of August 1949.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner stated that at the end of August, 1949, her husband returned to Malabar, in India.

facts.text: Petitioner's husband surreptitiously returned to India without a valid passport in 1953 and was arrested for infringement of the Foreigners Act.

anchor.surface_text: On behalf of respondent number 1, the Ministry of Rehabilitation, Government of India, it is averred that the petitioners husband surreptitiously returned to India without a valid passport in 1953 and was arrested for an alleged infringement of the provisions of the Foreigners Act.

facts.text: On December 7, 1953, Kunhi Moosa Haji transferred his right, title and interest in seven plots of land to his wife.

anchor.surface_text: On December 7, 1953, Kunhi Moosa Haji transferred in favour of his wife his right., title and interest in seven plots of land, details whereof are number necessary for our purpose.

facts.text: On December 8, 1954, a notice was issued to both the petitioner and her husband to show cause why Kunhi Moosa Haji should not be declared an evacuee and his property as evacuee property under the Administration of Evacuee Property Act, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: On December 8, 1954, about a year after the transfer, a numberice was issued to both the petitioner and her husband to show cause why Kunhi Moosa Haji should number be declared an evacuee and his property as evacuee property under the provisions of the Administration of Evacuee Property Act, 1950,  hereinafter called the Act .

facts.text: Petitioner's husband did not appear to contest the notice, but the petitioner entered appearance through her advocate.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioners husband did number appear to companytest the numberice, but the petitioner entered appearance through her advocate.

facts.text: By order dated January 29, 1955, the Assistant Custodian of Evacuee Property, Tellicherry, declared Kunhi Moosa Haji an evacuee under s. 2(d) of the Act and the plots evacuee property under s. 2(f).

anchor.surface_text: By an order dated January 29, 1955, the Assistant Custodian of Evacuee Property, Tellicherry, declared that Kunhi Moosa Haji was an evacuee under the provisions of s. 2 d  1  of the Act and the plots in question were evacuee property within the meaning of s. 2 f  of the Act.

facts.text: Petitioner appealed to the Deputy Custodian of Evacuee Property, Malabar, who affirmed the decision by order dated July 11, 1955.

anchor.surface_text: From this decision the petitioner unsuccessfully carried an appeal to the Deputy Custodian of Evacuee Property, Malabar, who affirmed the decision of the Assistant Custodian, Tellicherry, by his order dated July 11, 1955.

facts.text: Petitioner moved the Deputy Custodian for review under s. 26(2) of the Act, which failed.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner then moved the Deputy Custodian of Evacuee Property, Malabar, for a review of his order under s. 26 2  of the Act. This petition also failed.

facts.text: Petitioner moved Custodian-General of Evacuee Property, New Delhi, in revision, dismissed by order dated April 9, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: Then the petitioner moved the Custodian-General of Evacuee Property, New Delhi, in revision against the order of the Deputy Custodian. This revision petition was dismissed by the Custodian-General by his order dated April 9, 1956.

facts.text: Petitioner applied to Ministry of Rehabilitation for restoration of property under s. 16(1) of the Act, which was rejected.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner then made an application to the Ministry of Rehabilitation for an order of restoration of the property in her favour under the provisions of s. 16 1  of the Act. This application was also rejected.

facts.text: Petitioner moved High Court of Kerala by writ petition under Art. 226, which was withdrawn.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner then moved the High Court of Kerala by means of a writ petition under Art. 226 of the Constitution. This petition was, however, withdrawn by the petitioner on the ground that the Kerala High Court had held in an earlier decision...

facts.text: Present writ petition filed on March 5, 1959.

anchor.surface_text: Then, on March 5, 1959, the petitioner filed the present writ petition...

facts.text: Petitioner contests validity of notice issued on December 8, 1954 for non-compliance with rules and correctness of findings that husband was evacuee.

anchor.surface_text: In her petition, the petitioner has companytested the validity of the numberice issued on December 8, 1954, on the ground of numbercompliance with certain rules. She has also companytested on merits the companyrectness of the findings...

facts.text: Court finds no question of lack of jurisdiction involved as petitioner appeared and did not raise jurisdiction point earlier.

anchor.surface_text: Learned Counsel for the petitioner tried to argue that the invalidity of the numberice issued under s. 7 of the Act went to the root of jurisdiction... The petitioner appeared in response to the numberice and raised numberpoint of jurisdiction...

facts.text: No question of constitutionality of any law raised by petitioner.

anchor.surface_text: We need only add that numberquestion of the companystitutionality of any law is raised by the, petitioner.

facts.text: Custodian-General's order declared Kunhi Moosa Haji an evacuee under s. 2(d) and property evacuee property, and it has become final.

anchor.surface_text: ...the appropriate authorities of companypetent jurisdiction under the Act have determined... 1 that Kunhi Moosa Haji was an evacuee within the meaning of s. 2 d of the Act and 2 that his property was evacuee property... the order of the custodian General has become final.

facts.text: Under s. 28 of the Act, the order cannot be called in question in any court by way of appeal or revision or in any original suit.

anchor.surface_text: Under s. 28 of the Act the order cannot be called in question in any companyrt by way of an appeal or revision or in any original suit, application or execution proceeding.

facts.text: Petitioner did not challenge Custodian-General's decision by moving appropriate High Court or this Court by special leave.

anchor.surface_text: It was open to the petitioner to challenge the decision of the Custodian General, New Delhi, by moving the appropriate High Court... The petitioner did number, however, choose to do so.

facts.text: Kerala High Court held in Arthur Import Export Company v. Collector of Customs that High Court cannot issue writ to authority outside jurisdiction.

anchor.surface_text: ...the Kerala High Court had held in an earlier decision reported in Arthur Import Export Company, Bombay v. Colletor of Customs, Cochin  1  that when an order of an inferior tribunal is carried up in appeal or revision to a superior tribunal outside the companyrts jurisdiction...

facts.text: In Sahibzada Saiyed Muhammed Amirabbas Abbasi v. State of Madhya Bharat, this Court held cannot entertain Art. 32 petition where right does not exist due to prior competent decision.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Prior proceedings culminated in final unchalleged order of Custodian-General; petitioner did not pursue available remedies under Arts. 226 or 136

holdings.text: Under s. 28 of the Act the order cannot be called in question in any court by way of appeal or revision or original suit, but s. 28 cannot affect powers under Arts. 226, 227, 136, 32

anchor.surface_text: Under s. 28 of the Act the order cannot be called in question in any companyrt by way of an appeal or revision or in any original suit, application or execution proceeding. It is, indeed, true that s. 28 of the Act cannot affect the power of the High Court under Arts. 226 and 227 of the Constitution or of this Court under Arts. 136 and 32 of the Constitution.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory finality clause does not oust constitutional jurisdiction

holdings.text: Where on account of decision of competent authority the right alleged does not exist, no question of infringement of that right arises for petition under Art. 32

anchor.surface_text: Where, however, on account of the decision of an authority of companypetent jurisdiction the right alleged by the peti- tioner has been found number to exist, it is difficult to see bow any question of the infringement of that right can arise as a ground for a petition under Art. 32 of the Constitution, unless the decision of the authority of companypetent jurisdiction on the right alleged by the petitioner is held to be a nullity

holdings.reasoning_summary: Fundamental right claim dependent on overturning final administrative determination, which cannot be done under Art.32 without showing nullity

holdings.text: Principle from Sahibzada applies even where no special leave application was made; finality same whether challenged and rejected or not pursued

precedents.cited_proposition: where on account of the decision of a court of competent jurisdiction, the right alleged by the petitioner does not exist and, therefore, its infringement cannot arise, this Court cannot entertain a petition under Art. 32
